Department of Chemical Engineering, Hanyang University Seoul 04763 Republic of Korea The catalytic dehydrogenation of liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHC) is recognized as a structure-sensitive reaction, where the geometry, coordination and electronic environment of active sites govern activity, selectivity and durability in a collective fashion. Previous studies on monometallic catalysts revealed the critical roles of particle size, facet exposure and local coordination structures in controlling H2 release rate and byproduct formation. Built on these principles, bimetallic catalysts and metal–metal oxide hybrid catalysts have recently attracted growing interest. The former enables tunable metal compositions to modulate active site ensembles, while the latter introduces interfacial structures tailoring both electronic properties and structural resilience. However, their surfaces undergo dynamic evolution under realistic reaction environments. These include atom migration, metal redistribution and metal–oxide interface reconstruction, which can generate metastable active states that differ significantly from as-synthesized structures. To capture these complexities, in situ/operando characterization needs to be integrated with adaptive modeling approaches that can represent transient configurations and reaction-driven structural transformations. This review highlights recent advances in designing active sites across monometallic, bimetallic and metal–metal oxide systems. Furthermore, it outlines future directions toward the rational catalyst design affording dynamically resilient active sites for LOHC dehydrogenation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Liquid organic hydrogen carriers Dehydrogenation catalysis Structure sensitivity Active site design Multicomponent catalysts Structural dynamics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In building a future hydrogen economy society, critical technical challenges remain in hydrogen storage, particularly in industrial sectors that demand scalable, safe and efficient H2 delivery systems [1,2]. Among H2 storage strategies, liquid organic hydrogen carrier (LOHC) systems, based on organic compounds that remain in a liquid state during round-trip transportation between H2-demanding and H2-supplying sites, have gained increasing attention for their reversibility, chemical stability and compatibility with existing infrastructure [3,4]. Representative LOHC compounds that fulfill these criteria include methylcyclohexane (MCH), perhydro-benzyltoluene (H12-BT), perhydro-dibenzyltoluene (H18-DBT), perhydro-N-propylcarbazole (H12-NPC), and dodecahydro-N-ethylcarbazole (H12-NEC). In contrast, well-known hydrogen carriers such as formic acid and methanol violate the closed liquid-phase cycling fundamental to LOHC systems as their dehydrogenation yields gaseous products (CO2 and CO). The practical implementation of LOHC technologies is still constrained by the performance of dehydrogenation catalysts that frequently suffer from deactivation under harsh thermochemical conditions [5]. To guide future development, the European Commission has proposed a set of stringent performance targets [6]. These include a thermal energy requirement below 6 kWh kgH2 −1, H2 production rate exceeding 3 gH2 gcat −1 min−1, negligible performance loss (< 0.01 % per cycle), and catalyst lifetime exceeding five years with the conversion and selectivity maintained above 90 % and 99.8 %, respectively. In parallel, the liquid carrier itself must deliver a gravimetric hydrogen capacity greater than 5 wt % and a volumetric energy density above 1.6 MWh m−3. These rigorous criteria underscore the need for dehydrogenation catalysts that combine high activity with structural resistance to degradation during long-term operation. Typically, the LOHC dehydrogenation reaction involves sequential elementary steps: adsorption of a H2-rich reactant onto the metal surface, selective activation and cleavage of C–H bonds, and desorption of H2-lean products alongside H2 molecules [7]. As being broadly shared across many LOHC substrates, the overall dehydrogenation pathway exhibits substantial variation in the rate-determining step and the nature of active sites, depending on the carrier’s molecular structure, the metal type and the local surface environment [8,9]. Critically, controlling the structure of active sites determines catalytic dehydrogenation performance along with coke formation and metal sintering [10,11]. Nevertheless, homocyclic LOHC substrates often undergo side reactions to form undesirable byproducts, such as ring-opening and excessive dehydrogenation [12,13]. Heterocyclic substrates, particularly nitrogen-containing carriers, are also known to experience the cleavage of C–N or C–C bonds while showing the selective C–H activation at milder conditions [14,15]. These complexities emphasize the importance of understanding a dynamic response under reaction conditions and identifying structural features to ensure long-term performance. Monometallic catalysts played an essential role in the early development of LOHC dehydrogenation technology and provided benchmark systems to evaluate the activity, selectivity and stability. However, these catalyst systems offer limited tunability with respect to geometric and electronic control of active sites [16]. As the dehydrogenation of LOHC is now widely recognized as a structure-sensitive reaction [17,18], many efforts have been shifted toward catalyst systems to enable fine tuning of local structural environments. In particular, bimetallic catalysts and metal–metal oxide hybrid catalysts offer opportunities to manipulate metal composition, interfacial site structure and surface defects, which can directly modulate C–H bond activation [19,20], suppress undesired bond cleavage [21,22], and/or promote efficient product desorption [23,24]. Although these experimental approaches examined promising improvements, a full understanding of how engineered structural features influence each of elementary steps in LOHC dehydrogenation remains incomplete. Recent reviews discussed diverse perspectives in LOHC dehydrogenation, including system-level integration and reactor optimization [25], catalyst development tailored to specific substrates [26], comparative analysis of active metals and supports [27], and theoretical modeling based on density functional theory (DFT) using descriptors derived from reaction energetics [28]. Many of these contributions, though offering important insights, remain limited on isolated systems and still lack a cohesive framework linking catalyst structure to catalytic behavior throughout a sequence of full dehydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, critical parameters such as metal composition, interfacial charge distribution, and local coordination are insufficiently understood in terms of their influence on dehydrogenation performance and stability. Motivated by such challenges, this review aims to establish a comprehensive structure–function framework for the development of LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts, which is essential to guide the next generation of catalyst designs. Given the performance criteria for real-world application, this review gives more attention to cyclic LOHC systems that meet the minimum thresholds in hydrogen capacity and reversibility. Beginning with monometallic catalysts, we analyze the governing factors in their geometric and electronic properties. The discussion then extends to recent advances in bimetallic catalysts and metal–metal oxide catalysts, based on compositional tuning, interfacial design and coordination control. Catalyst structures exhibit dynamic behavior under operating conditions. We discuss structural evolution studies to highlight metastable configurations and transient active sites. Finally, limitations in current theoretical modeling approaches are examined with emphasis on the need for predictive frameworks accounting for realistic reaction environments. This approach helps identify knowledge gaps and guide the rational design of robust LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts. 2 Critical challenges in monometallic LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts 2.1 Substrate-specific side reactions While the general mechanism of LOHC dehydrogenation is well established, the structural requirements to achieve high performance remain highly dependent on the specific substrate and catalyst system. The side reactions of homocyclic and heterocyclic LOHCs differ in their pathways and products, yet both are frequently driven by the strong and persistent adsorption of intermediate products [7,9]. These adsorption behaviors underscore the structure sensitivity of LOHC dehydrogenation, emphasizing the critical role of site geometry in catalytic activity and product selectivity. In light of these challenges, successful balancing of high activity with resistance to side reactions relies on precise control over the distribution of active sites, such as terraces, step edges and defect-rich ensembles. It also demands the ability to tune their electronic and steric environments to align with the specific requirements of different LOHC substrates. Rather than recalling general principles, this section focuses on experimental evidences that can clarify when and how the structure sensitivity is manifested in LOHC dehydrogenation catalysis. It is increasingly recognized that product selectivity is often compromised by substrate-specific side reactions occurring at structurally and electronically distinct active sites. For instance, homocyclic molecules such as MCH, H12-BT and H18-DBT are susceptible to ring opening or excessive dehydrogenation over under-coordinated metal sites. In contrast, heterocyclic LOHC molecules, including H12-NPC and H12-NEC, are more prone to cleavage of C–C or C–N bond, particularly at the sites where strong reactant adsorption disrupts selective C–H activation [29]. These reaction patterns illustrate the need to adapt active site environments, both geometrically and electronically, to distinct adsorption and reaction characteristics of different LOHC substrates. Adjusting reactant coordination, site accessibility and adsorption strength is essential to suppress side reactions and ensure high selectivity. 2.2 Structure sensitivity of LOHC dehydrogenation The dehydrogenation reaction frequently exhibits structure-sensitive behavior, in which catalytic activity and selectivity depend strongly on surface features such as particle size, exposed facets and ensemble configurations. A representative example is the dehydrogenation of H12-NEC, where both experimental and computational studies revealed clear size-dependent trends. An early study on Pd/SiO2 catalysts identified an optimal particle size around 9 nm for maximizing both turnover frequency (TOF) and selectivity, attributed to the formation of multi-atom ensembles that stabilize reaction intermediates [30]. Moreover, Pd catalysts with precisely defined coordination environments were synthesized, spanning from isolated atoms to multilayered nanoparticles, and evaluated for H12-NEC dehydrogenation [31]. The site-specific TOF displayed a volcano-shaped dependence on the Pd–Pd coordination number (CN), reaching a maximum at the CN ≈ 4.4 corresponding to fully exposed Pd nanoclusters ( Fig. 1a). This optimal coordination offered a favorable balance between reactant activation and product desorption, clearly outperforming single atoms and bulk-like particles. Consistently, the dehydrogenation activity of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts varied with Pt particle size; specifically for larger Pt nanoparticles (∼4.6 nm) facilitating the conversion to N-ethylcarbazole (H0-NEC) [32]. These trends collectively support that H12-NEC dehydrogenation is structure-sensitive across both Pd- and Pt-based systems, particularly in the later dehydrogenation steps where selective C–H activation becomes more demanding. The dehydrogenation of H12-BT and H18-DBT also exhibited strong structure sensitivity. Among various sizes of Pt nanoparticle in Pt/Al2O3, those in the range of 2.3–2.7 nm delivered the highest initial H2 productivity, which was linked to a favorable balance between terrace and under-coordinated sites [18]. In addition, low-temperature activity was correlated with the formation of B5-type ensembles, specific multi-atom configurations located at step-edge junctions to promote C–H bond activation, as evident from the stronger size dependence at 220 °C and 230 °C (Fig. 1b). Additional evidence of structure sensitivity came from cyclohexane dehydrogenation, where few-atom Pt ensembles with a Pt–Pt CN close to 2 delivered the highest TOF value (Fig. 1c) [17]. These confined ensembles could provide an environment favorable for C–H bond activation and reduced the likelihood of product inhibition. Interestingly, MCH dehydrogenation presented contrasting observations, depending on catalyst systems. In Pd nanoparticles supported on SiO2, the reaction rate was insensitive to particle size or dispersion [33]. This behavior was attributed to the formation of dense organic adlayers under reaction conditions, limiting the access to structurally distinct surface sites. In contrast, a study on Pt/Al2O3 described a clear particle size dependence, with intermediate-sized Pt nanoparticles (0.7–1.2 nm for 0.1 wt% Pt) yielding the highest activity at 200 °C and 240 °C (Fig. 1d) [16]. These examples demonstrate that structure sensitivity in LOHC dehydrogenation depends on the catalyst system. Metal identity, support interactions and surface dynamics collectively shape this behavior. However, monometallic catalysts often lack structural and electronic flexibility to significantly alter site-specific properties. In particular, it remains challenging to simultaneously achieve high dispersion and selective exposure of reactive sites, limiting their tunability for structure-sensitive reactions. 2.3 Constraints of non-metallic additives to modulate structure-sensitive features To expand the structural tunability of active metal sites, various additive strategies have been developed. Among them, non-metallic elements such as sulfur and phosphorus have received particular attention due to their ability to influence site reactivity and suppress undesired reactions. Sulfur additive was reported to improve the product selectivity by selectively blocking under-coordinated Pt sites that promote byproduct formation. In CO-chemisorbed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (CO-DRIFT) spectra ( Fig. 2a), sulfur species sequentially bound to corner, edge and terrace Pt atoms with increasing the sulfur loading, thereby modulating CO adsorption behavior and tuning surface ensemble accessibility. In Pt/Al2O3, sulfur modification suppressed the formation of methylfluorene (MF) and other high-boiling products [34–36], originating from deep dehydrogenation of benzyltoluene (H0-BT) at the final stage of H12-BT conversion [5,37]. This concept is illustrated by depicting how sulfur decoration facilitates rapid product desorption and limits over-dehydrogenation (Fig. 2b). The data revealed the increased resistance of sulfur-decorated Pt nanoclusters to competitive adsorption of H0-BT when co-fed with H12-BT. This result supports the interpretation that MF formation is suppressed under substrate-mixed conditions. Similar behavior was observed in S–Pt/TiO2 system, where the reducible support induces strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) that alter the electronic structure of Pt [38,39]. These catalysts achieved both high H2 release, as measured by the degree of dehydrogenation (DOD), and consistently low MF selectivity during extended operation (Fig. 2c). This outcome demonstrates the role of adsorption control in improving catalyst selectivity and thermal stability. A key challenge, however, is sulfur loss under H2-rich conditions at elevated temperatures, which can deteriorate long-term performance and affect H2 purity. In contrast, phosphorus-modified Pt catalysts provided greater thermal stability and effectively stabilized Pt nanoparticles even after high-temperature treatment [40,41]. Appropriate phosphorus loading could enhance Pt dispersion and suppress sintering without formation of inactive metal phosphide phases. On the other hand, phosphorus promotion led to a sharp increase in MF formation with the DOD (Fig. 2d), suggesting that the P-modified catalyst accelerates over-dehydrogenation. While it effectively improves dispersion and thermal stability, its ability to control adsorption selectivity and prevent byproduct formation is still limited. In summary, non-metallic additives offer practical benefits in improving metal dispersion and tuning adsorption characteristics. Yet, they lack the structural precision and long-term robustness required to fully control active site distribution under LOHC operating conditions. Consequently, the optimal design window differs by substrate: H12‑NEC benefits from moderating ensemble size and electron density to avoid C–N and C–C cleavage; MCH requires confined or distorted ensembles that weaken aromatic adsorption and limit coke precursors; H12‑BT and H18‑DBT demand terrace‑rich surfaces with under‑coordinated sites selectively blocked and electronic states tuned to suppress over‑dehydrogenation products such as fluorene-based materials. To address these substrate-specific needs, catalyst design shifted toward metal-based and interfacial strategies (Sections 3 and 4). These strategies integrate composition control, ensemble geometry and interfacial charge tuning to enhance precision. 3 Bimetallic catalysts for LOHC dehydrogenation Bimetallic catalysts have been advanced from simple metal pairings to alloys whose composition, ensemble geometry and electron density are deliberately engineered at the atomic scale. By fine‑tuning these parameters, they overcome the constraints of monometallic and additive‑modified systems and deliver notable gains in H2 productivity, selectivity and durability. Table 1 lists the representative systems covered in this section, grouping them by the reactant and reporting their composition, key structural/electronic attributes and qualitative performance. These improvements have been reproduced across an expanding set of LOHC substrates, confirming that careful control of alloy architecture directly translates into superior dehydrogenation performance. 3.1 Metal alloying to tune surface reactivity A central objective in the design of bimetallic catalysts is to achieve high H2 release rates without compromising H2 selectivity, primarily through the modulation of active metal’s electronic and structural environments. Controlled alloying between noble and transition metals enables such modifications by altering surface ensemble configurations and adsorption energetics. Fang and coworkers investigated Pd-based bimetallic catalysts for H12-NEC dehydrogenation, showing that both the identity of the secondary metal (M = Co, Ni, Cu) and the Pd:M ratio influence catalytic performance [42,43]. In their studies, Pd3Ni1/SiO2 exhibited a 42.4 % increase in TOF relative to its monometallic counterpart, ascribed to the modified surface electronic structure and optimized ensemble configuration. Furthermore, the activity comparison of Pd–M/Al2O3 suggested that Pd1Co1/Al2O3 delivered the highest performance of 95.3 % H2 yield and 85.4 % selectivity toward H0-NEC at a TOF of 230.5 min−1. Compared to Pd/Al2O3, this corresponded to a 14.3 % increase in H2 release and a nearly-doubled H0-NEC selectivity. This enhancement stemmed from the favorable Pd–Co interaction that could stabilize active ensembles and modulate adsorption behavior, whereas Ni- and Cu-added catalysts showed lower activity under similar operating conditions. Recent studies on Pt–Sn systems demonstrated that the alloying degree critically influences phase formation and catalytic performance. The structure–performance relationship was obtained by varying the Sn/Pt ratio at the fixed preparation conditions [44]: increasing the Sn content induced a gradual transition from Pt nanoclusters to Pt–Sn clusters, Pt3Sn and finally PtSn nanoparticles ( Fig. 3a). This structural evolution was accompanied by the formation of SnO x species and progressive reduction of adjacent Pt–Pt sites, which facilitated product desorption and suppressed coke formation in MCH dehydrogenation. Among the tested compositions, the Pt–Sn(2)/Al2O3 (Sn/Pt molar ratio = 2) was identified to exhibit the highest durability and selectivity. This composition–structure understanding was further refined through thermal treatment studies. The calcination of Pt–Sn/Al2O3 at 450 °C and 700 °C resulted in the structurally distinct phases of loosely associated bimetallics and fully alloyed Pt3Sn, respectively [21] (Fig. 3b). In H18-DBT dehydrogenation, the catalyst synthesized via organometallic approach achieved TOFs of 33–135 min−1, far exceeding that of a catalyst prepared by impregnation (5.4 min−1), primarily due to more uniform alloy formation. While the bimetallic phase delivered the highest activity, the fully alloyed Pt3Sn phase provided the greater selectivity. In a complementary effort, a recent study introduced Pt3Sb/SiO2 as a structurally defined intermetallic catalyst designed to decouple geometric effects from electronic influences [22]. Although Pt3Sb(114) and Pt3Sn(111) shared an almost identical d‑band center of ∼ −2.55 eV, the distorted triangular Pt3 motifs on the Pt3Sb(114) surface weakened toluene adsorption (E ad = −35.4 kJ mol−1, compared with −58.2 kJ mol−1 on Pt3Sn(111)) (Fig. 3c). The same geometric distortion also raised the demethylation barrier; hence, Pt3Sb catalyst displayed higher durability and selectivity in MCH dehydrogenation. This finding demonstrates that precise geometric control can rival alloy composition and phase in governing catalytic performance and stability. 3.2 Ensemble tailoring via site isolation and spatial confinement Although effective in tuning composition and electronic properties, the alloying strategy offers limited control over the precise arrangement of surface ensembles. This limitation becomes particularly problematic in the systems where dehydrogenation products are bulky and contain aromatic π-conjugated frameworks tending to bind strongly and hinder efficient desorption. To mitigate these challenges, the approaches of ensemble dilution and spatial isolation have been developed to enhance product selectivity without compromising catalytic activity. In Ni–Sn intermetallic systems, the metal alloying led to the formation of Ni3Sn-type structures that reduce ensemble size and alter adsorption strength [45]. This geometric refinement effectively suppressed C–C bond cleavage, resulting in 99.9 % selectivity at 60 % MCH conversion along with the competitive activity relative to a pure Ni catalyst. To further limit the ensemble’s growth with maintaining the activity, a Ni@Pd core-shell catalyst was developed on KIT-6 using ultrasound-assisted galvanic replacement [46]. In this system, the spatial decoupling of reactive Pd shell from Ni core suppressed the formation of large Pd ensembles while retaining high intrinsic activity. The prepared catalyst was more active and selective in H12-NEC dehydrogenation than monometallic Pd/KIT-6, emphasizing the structural isolation in tuning the surface reactivity without sacrificing metal utilization. A Pt single atom alloy with an Fe overlayer supported on Cu nanoparticles was developed to extend this concept. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) analysis identified atomic Pt–Fe ensembles at the Fe interface. These ensembles markedly improved activity and coking resistance in MCH dehydrogenation (Fig. 3d) [47]. The Fe overlayer provided a low-crystalline environment and acted as a decoking interface, while stabilizing isolated Pt atoms on the surface. The resulting structure achieved a 133-fold improvement in H2 evolution rate per gram Pt compared to state-of-the-art intermetallic catalysts. A complementary approach involved encapsulating PtSn nanoparticles within a silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite matrix via one-pot hydrothermal synthesis [48]. The Sn/Pt ratio was tuned up to 6 to induce the formation of core-shell architectures, where Pt cores were stabilized by Sn-rich shell confined within the pores of S-1. The resulting Pt1Sn6@S-1 catalyst with the Sn/Pt molar ratio of 6 exhibited the most favorable performance. Such confinement prevented nanoparticle growth and aggregation (Fig. 3e), resulting in high MCH conversion and nearly 100 % toluene selectivity even under accelerated flow conditions. Electronic and geometric characterizations supported the encapsulated structure. Zeolite encapsulation modified the Pt–Sn interaction and the local environment around Sn, enabling finely tuned electron density, improved toluene desorption and enhanced coke resistance (Fig. 3f). These effects collectively contributed to long-term stability under harsh conditions. Tailoring surface ensembles through alloying, dilution or confinement is critical to direct reaction pathways and lift catalytic performance. Building on the substrate-specific requirements summarized in Section 2, bimetallic designs rely on three main levers: composition control, ensemble geometry (e.g., size, continuity, coordination) and confinement length scale. These regulate adsorption and site stability, suppressing undesired bond cleavage and coke formation while maintaining high H2 release. They also set the stage for the metal–oxide interfaces discussed in the next section, where similar control is achieved through interfacial charge and geometry. 4 Metal–metal oxide interfacial catalysts for LOHC dehydrogenation Metal–oxide interfaces extend the principles of alloy design by enabling localized control over active sites through charge redistribution and spatial confinement. By selectively modifying electronic states and restricting the accessibility of under-coordinated sites, these interfacial structures regulate key surface processes such as adsorption and desorption. As a result, they stabilize reactive motifs, mitigate deactivation, and promote sustained H2 release and product selectivity under realistic LOHC conditions. This design approach overcomes limitations of purely metallic systems and offers a versatile, substrate-responsive platform for robust dehydrogenation catalysis, with representative systems briefly outlined in Table 2. 4.1 Interfacial electronic modulation via metal oxide additives The catalytic performance of noble metals in LOHC dehydrogenation is strongly influenced by their interfacial interaction with metal oxide additives. Such interactions can induce directional charge transfer depending on the pairing of metal and oxide, as governed by the work function difference, Fermi level alignment and d-band characteristics. These interfacial effects offer a rational handle for the activity, selectivity and stability through tuning the electronic environment of the active site. Among various systems, Pd–BaO/Al2O3 represents a case of electron donation from the oxide to the metal. This modification increased the fraction of metallic Pd0 to promote C–H activation. As visualized in the maps of charge density and electrostatic potential maps, a well-defined Pd–BaO interface, especially supported on Ba3Al2O6, facilitated electron accumulation on Pd ( Fig. 4a). This interfacial structure was associated with weakened metal–support interaction, contributing to enhanced H2 release and cycling durability [49]. MoO x -modified catalysts demonstrated the behavior of metal-dependent charge transfer. An optimal Mo loading (0.18 wt%) in Pd–MoO x /Al2O3 promoted the formation of Lewis acidic MoO x nanoclusters being able to accept electrons from Pd [24]. This was supported by the analysis of wavelet transform extended X-ray absorption fine structure (WT-EXAFS), where a distinct Pd–Mo scattering contribution appeared around 3 Å in addition to intensified Mo–O features (Fig. 4b). Low MoO x coverage produces Mo–Pd but no Mo–Mo scattering, indicating isolated clusters on Pd, whereas higher coverage introduces Mo–Mo contributions and weakens Mo–Pd, consistent with MoO x agglomeration. These Mo–Pd signals verify direct Pd–MoO x contact, providing the interface needed for electron transfer. Moreover, the concomitant drop in support work function (ϕ) (from 5.73 eV to 5.60 eV, close to ϕ Pd = 3.64 eV), together with the band‑alignment diagram that places the Pd Fermi level above the MoO x conduction band, verifies net electron transfer from Pd to the Lewis‑acidic MoO x (Fig. 4c). Conversely, Pt–MoO x /Al2O3 exhibited an opposite direction of charge transfer. Due to the higher work function of Pt than Pd, electrons were donated from MoO x to Pt, as evidenced by positive shifts in the binding energy of Pt 4d core level observed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 4d). This electron enrichment at Pt sites enhanced H2 spillover and concurrently suppressed MF formation during H12-BT dehydrogenation [50]. Such an electronic modification at the Pt–MoO x interface highlights the metal-specific nature of charge transfer in oxide-modified systems. MnO x -based systems demonstrated that even with the same oxide, the formation of effective charge transfer pathways critically depends on how the metal–oxide interface is engineered. In the same study [50], Pt–MnO x /Al2O3 improved the activity but did not induce significant electronic changes in Pt, resulting in increased side reaction. By contrast, when MnO x was introduced via a solvent-deficient precipitation followed by rapid reduction, the resulting mesoporous Pt–MnO x –Al2O3 formed highly coupled interfacial domains. This structure promoted localized charge transfer from Pt to adjacent MnO x , producing positively charged Pt nanoclusters. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) showed a distinct “green” peak in mPt0.33MnA, attributed to electron‑deficient Pt created by this charge transfer; the peak was absent in monometallic Pt (mPtA) and Mn (m0.33MnA) catalysts (Fig. 4e). The optimized catalyst delivered 94 % H2 release with significantly reduced MF formation [51]. Similar partially positively charged metal species have been reported in Pt–Ga2O3/Al2O3 and Pd–FeO x /Al2O3, where the electron withdrawal from the metal surface improved dehydrogenation selectivity and long-term performance [23,52]. Further interfacial modulation was achieved in Pt–ReO x /Al2O3 showing efficient low-temperature H12-BT dehydrogenation at 210–250 °C [53]. Progressive electronic changes with increasing Re loading were captured by in situ X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) analysis (Fig. 4f). A gradual increase in Pt L 3-edge white line intensity indicated increased d-band vacancy and partial Pt oxidation. Conversely, the Re L 3-edge intensity decreased, reflecting partial reduction of Re species. This dynamic interfacial electronic redistribution was proposed to promote selective C–H bond activation while preventing excessive dehydrogenation during reaction. In summary, the above findings emphasize that interfacial charge redistribution is not only governed by metal–oxide pairing but also controlled through structural and synthetic tuning of the interface. By rational design of oxide composition, loading and spatial contact with noble metal sites, catalysts can be electronically engineered to direct adsorption energetics, product desorption and byproduct suppression. Wherever electrons are donated to or withdrawn from the metal, interfacial structure–function relationships offer a powerful framework to design active LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts. 4.2 Surface geometry tailoring by addition of stabilizing additives The geometric structure of catalytic sites, including spatial configuration, local coordination and confinement, plays a vital role in governing both activity and stability in LOHC dehydrogenation. In contrast to the approaches focusing solely on electronic modification, recent studies have pursued geometric tailoring to control site exposure, limit unselective pathways and resist structural degradation. An example is Pt–SnO x /Al2O3 in which Sn species at the metal–support interface act as structural modulators. DFT simulation revealed that the interfacial Sn strengthened Pt–Al2O3 interaction and reduced the ductility of Pt13 nanoclusters [20]. This rigidity hindered the adsorption of late intermediates and thereby mitigated coke formation during MCH dehydrogenation. Geometric refinement was observed in Pt–CrO x /Al2O3. The addition of CrO x reduced the abundance of under-coordinated Pt species and preserved an electron-enriched surface [54]. These effects were analogous to those observed in NbO x -modified systems, where surface restructuring favored terrace-rich Pt geometries and limited step and kink sites [55]. CO‑DRIFT spectra showed that as Nb loading increased, the linear‑CO band for edge/step Pt sites shifted from 2047 cm−1 to 2065 cm−1 and its area decreased by roughly half. Meanwhile, the terrace‑site band blue‑shifted from 2071 cm−1 to 2086 cm−1 and the oxidized‑Pt band at 2101–2116 cm−1 intensified ( Fig. 5a). These trends indicate that growing NbO x nanoclusters preferentially envelop under‑coordinated Pt, withdrawing electron density and effectively blocking step and kink sites without covering terrace sites. By suppressing linear CO adsorption, Nb incorporation raised the DOD while keeping MF formation below 1.5 % (Fig. 5b), thereby improving selective C–H activation during the dehydrogenation of H18-DBT and H12-BT. Support composition and porosity could also be utilized to engineer active-site geometry. A Pd–CoO x /Zr-C3N4 catalyst exhibited high H12-NEC conversion at 140 °C, facilitated by the conductive and heteroatom-rich nature of Zr-C3N4 framework [56]. In a separate study, the Sn modification of carbon support yielded a Pd–CoO x /Sn-C catalyst with expanded pores, enhanced metal dispersion and strong metal–support contact. The Sn-C-supported catalyst achieved 99.3 % conversion and 92.5 % selectivity, outperforming the unmodified catalyst [57]. These results highlight the importance of support’s structural properties influencing both accessibility and anchoring of active ensembles. At a more confined scale, the encapsulation via zeolite provided an effective method to preserve small metal nanocluster geometry. In a Pt–Fe system embedded within the MFI framework, strong spatial restriction confined nanoclusters to the sub-nanometer regime and stabilized under-coordinated Pt ensembles (Fig. 5c) [19]. This confinement rendered high H2 utilization efficiency and sustained > 99.9 % toluene selectivity during 2000 h of MCH dehydrogenation (Fig. 5d), underscoring the merit of zeolitic environments in minimizing structural rearrangement. These findings affirm that the surface geometry tailoring assessed through promoter-induced restructuring, support architecture or nanoscale confinement can offer versatile strategies to improve selectivity, prevent coking and maintain structural stability. When integrated with interfacial electronic control (discussed in Section 4.1), such design approaches provide a cohesive platform for advancing LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts under demanding reaction conditions. Unlike alloy-based strategies that primarily rely on global compositional tuning, interfacial catalysts enable site-specific modulation through controlled charge redistribution, selective masking of under-coordinated sites and confinement of active domains. These localized structural and electronic controls regulate key surface processes such as substrate adsorption, intermediate transformation and product desorption, allowing for pathway-selective catalysis across various LOHC substrates. By integrating geometric and electronic precision at the metal–oxide interface, this approach expands the design space beyond traditional alloying, offering a structurally robust and substrate-responsive platform for efficient and durable H2 release. Nevertheless, these engineered interfaces remain structurally dynamic under realistic reaction environments, motivating a closer look at how active sites evolve in operation. 5 Structural dynamics of LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts under reaction conditions 5.1 Dynamic changes in catalytic sites under working conditions Under the elevated temperatures and reducing atmospheres typical of LOHC dehydrogenation, catalyst surfaces undergo continuous atomic rearrangement. These reaction-induced environments frequently drive metal atom migration, structural rearrangement and adsorbate-driven encapsulation, significantly reshaping the configuration of an active site. For instance, Pd nanoparticles supported on Al2O3 were transformed into metastable Pd6C phase during MCH dehydrogenation. This change occurred through dynamic decomposition into graphene and carbon diffusion under reaction conditions, which impacts catalytic activity and stability [58]. Dynamic restructuring driven by redox environments was exemplified by Pd–Au/SiO2 catalysts ( Fig. 6a). Modulation excitation X-ray absorption spectroscopy (ME-XAS) under alternating H2 and O2 pulses revealed cyclic transformation between Pd-rich metallic surfaces and oxidized PdO x domains. During O2 exposure, surface Pd atoms were segregated to PdO x islands, which were subsequently reduced and redispersed during H2 pulses. This reversible restructuring highlights redox-driven modulation of surface composition and active site accessibility [59]. The analogous reversible redox-induced transition between PdO and Pd0 was similarly observed on Pd–Au/Al2O3, further supporting the dynamic restructuring behavior in bimetallic catalyst systems [60]. Under reducing atmospheres (H2), the intrinsic mobility of single Pt atoms significantly contributed to structural evolution (Fig. 6b). In situ STEM imaging demonstrated rapid atomic migration and coalescence of isolated Pt atoms into nanoclusters during H2 exposure to Pt/Al2O3. Complementary DFT calculations confirmed that oxidizing conditions stabilize isolated Pt atoms via strong anchoring, whereas reducing conditions enhance their mobility and lead to dynamic formation of Pt nanoclusters​​​​​​ [61]. Alloy composition strongly influences restructuring dynamics, as observed for Pt–M/C systems (M = Fe, Co, Ni). Surface enrichment by transition metals increases nanoparticle mobility and promotes coalescence at elevated temperatures. Specifically, Ni-rich surfaces exhibited the highest mobility and fastest particle coalescence, Fe-rich surfaces showed intermediate behavior, and Co- or Pt-rich surfaces displayed significantly enhanced structural stability. These trends suggested that alloy surface composition critically could dictate restructuring behavior under reaction conditions [62]. Fig. 6c illustrates that thermal treatment in PtFe3 nanoparticles first induces Fe surface enrichment (green regions) and subsequently leads to the formation of Fe–Pt intermetallic domains (red regions), thereby stabilizing catalytic sites and modifying catalytic reactivity. Redox-active metal oxide supports also drive significant restructuring behaviors. Atomically dispersed Pt–Sn species on CeO2 were reversibly assembled into PtSn3 nanoclusters and disassembled under reducing (encountered upon catalytic dehydrogenation) and reoxidizing environments, respectively (Fig. 6d). This adaptive restructuring was facilitated by the redox-active CeO2 support, which changed catalyst geometry and oxidation states according to gas-phase conditions [63]. Similarly, Rh nanoparticles supported on TiO2 underwent adsorbate-mediated structural transformations under CO2/H2 atmospheres (Fig. 6e). Surface-bound HCO x intermediates promoted the migration of partially reduced TiO x over Rh nanoparticles. This formed an amorphous overlayer that modulated reaction selectivity without significantly altering the Rh core geometry [64]. Ni/SiO2 catalysts also demonstrated particle size-dependent restructuring. Quick-XAS experiments under alternating pulses of hydrogen and ethene revealed reversible expansion and contraction (named "breathing") of Ni–Ni bonds in larger Ni nanoparticles (Fig. 6f). In the representative 4.4 nm-particles pictured, the Ni–Ni distance expanded from about 2.49 Å (hydrogen) to 2.54 Å (ethene), then contracted back within seconds after hydrogen was re‑introduced, giving a reversible amplitude of roughly 2.4 %. Sub-nanometer clusters, by contrast, exhibited changes of < 0.01 Å, confirming that larger particles possess far greater structural flexibility [65]. A comparable size-dependent response was observed for Pt/Al2O3. Temperature-dependent EXAFS measurement revealed negative thermal expansion: the Pt–Pt distance in 0.9 nm nanoclusters contracted from 2.70 Å at 200 K to 2.66 Å at 800 K (∼1.5 % shrinkage), in contrast to the positive expansion of bulk Pt (Fig. 6g). This contraction weakened in 1.1 nm and 2.9 nm particles, indicating that negative thermal expansion is confined to small clusters with non‑bulk electronic states and enhanced metal–support interaction [66]. Thus, the observed restructuring phenomena collectively reflect a complex interplay involving metal mobility, alloy composition, support reducibility, particle size and adsorbate-driven process. Considering dynamic structural evolutions via operando spectroscopy and microscopy is crucial to elucidate true catalytic mechanisms and further to design catalysts that are robust and adaptable under realistic conditions. 5.2 Structural reorganization of alloy catalysts to limit static modeling approaches For the catalysts categorized as alloy-type or metal–metal oxide hybrid systems based on their as-synthesized structures, emerging experimental evidences demonstrated that the dynamic structural evolution could not be adequately captured under working conditions. Even the catalysts initially formed as homogeneous alloys frequently experienced substantial restructuring during reaction, leading to surface segregation, partial oxidation and the formation of metal–oxide interfacial domains. Traditional static models assume that catalyst surfaces retain a fixed atomic arrangement composed of terrace, edge and step sites ( Fig. 7a). However, under reaction conditions, catalysts undergo continuous restructuring, activating different atomic ensembles over time and accessing metastable configurations along the reaction coordinate [67]. The thermodynamic driving forces underlying these transformations primarily involve differences in redox potentials, cohesive energies and oxygen affinities between constituent metals. For example, Pt–Cu and Pt–Zn alloys, which possess relatively similar oxygen affinities and cohesive behaviors, tended to preserve their alloy structures even under reactive environments. In contrast, Pt–Fe, Pt–Mn, and Pt–Sn alloys, which contain oxophilic secondary metals, were prone to surface oxidation and segregation, leading to the formation of FeO x , MnO x , and SnO x domains at the catalyst–support interface. Owing to their higher oxygen affinity and redox activity relative to Pt, the secondary metals induced structural rearrangements, forming localized oxide-modified active sites distinct from the initial alloy configuration. Additional observations showed that even relatively stable Pt–Pd and Ni–Y alloys undergo surface segregation and oxide phase formation under oxidative conditions, further emphasizing the intrinsic metastability of many alloy systems [68]. In a broad review on LOHC catalyst modeling, Han et al. pointed out that most computational studies are still based on idealized surfaces and static geometries, which limits their ability to capture metastable configurations and dynamic metal–oxide interface formation critical under operando conditions [28]. Despite the growing use of atomistic simulations in catalyst design, conventional modeling approaches still optimize structures under vacuum or inert conditions, assuming static, homogeneous alloy distributions associated with energy minima. These models typically failed to account for reaction-induced surface restructuring, adsorbate-driven segregation, coverage-dependent adsorption modes or redox behavior of supports. Current computational strategies rely on features such as coordination number, cohesive energy and electronegativity difference, often combined with the average adsorbate–metal bond length, derived from idealized static alloy structures (Fig. 7b). These features are then used for training machine learning models and predicting catalytic properties. For example, the toluene adsorption energies (ΔE ads,TOL) were computed on a diverse set of Pt–M bimetallic active sites and used to train a Gaussian‑process regression model; predictions for additional dopants are shown alongside the training data in Fig. 7c. All values assume stable homogeneous surfaces and do not include restructuring effects [69]. Though providing valuable insights into dopant trends, static predictions overlooked the potential for surface segregation or interfacial oxidation. Likewise, microkinetic simulations built on static energetics can miss pathway shifts when site evolution or coverage effects are omitted, potentially misleading activity and selectivity predictions (Fig. 7d). Recent reviews emphasized that overcoming these limitations requires the development of adaptive simulation frameworks that incorporate thermodynamic driving forces, dynamic gas-phase effects and metastable state accessibility [70,71]. Such integration is indispensable for future catalyst development toward the systems maintaining high performance under reaction environments. 6 Conclusions and outlook LOHC dehydrogenation catalysis has progressed rapidly in recent years, with accumulating evidence supporting its classification as a structure-sensitive reaction. A number of studies on monometallic catalysts demonstrated that catalytic activity and selectivity are highly dependent on the geometry and electronic properties of active metals. This progress has led to increasing focus on bimetallic and metal–metal oxide catalysts. In particular, the field has witnessed a marked growth in strategic approaches on compositional tuning, interfacial modification and coordination control, reflecting a shift from empirical optimization to rational, structure–function-guided catalyst design. Despite these advances, catalyst performance remains highly susceptible to structural transformations under reaction conditions. High-temperature and reductive environments can induce atom migration, alloy redistribution and changes in oxidation states, altering the coordination and distribution of active sites. These dynamic structural phenomena are challenging to capture with conventional ex situ techniques and often lead to discrepancies between the observed catalytic behavior and the assumed static structures. In parallel, theoretical modeling remains limited by its reliance on idealized surfaces and static geometries, typically omitting surface heterogeneities, adsorbate-induced restructuring and metal–oxide interfacial phenomena. As a result, metastable active states critically influencing catalytic performance under operando conditions are often overlooked. To meet these challenges, static structural design principles would be integrated with understanding dynamic catalyst evolution. The ability to observe and predict changes in active site structure, coordination and composition during operation is essential for bridging a gap between rational catalyst design and practical performance. To link spatial design of active sites with their temporal evolution during reaction, future progress will depend on advances in four key areas: 1. Interfacial and coordination control: Emphasis should be placed on designing catalysts with electronically tunable yet structurally resilient interfaces. Tailoring local coordination environments can suppress deactivation pathways and promote selective H2 release from various LOHC substrates. 2. Advanced characterization: Real-time spectroscopic and microscopic techniques, including in situ/operando XAS, DRIFT and STEM, can track the evolution of active sites under working conditions. These insights will support more accurate mechanistic interpretation and enable refinement of catalyst models based on actual performance. 3. Scale‑up and industrial robustness: Laboratory‑designed catalyst structures must be reproducibly maintained during kilogram‑scale production, and durability should be verified through > 500 h accelerated tests that replicate industrial flow rates, impurity levels, and periodic regeneration cycles. Major challenges include batch‑to‑batch consistency, resistance to thermal cycling and common poisons, and effective heat management during operation. 4. Dynamic and adaptive modeling approaches: Future simulations should move beyond static approximations in order to capture time-dependent restructuring, metal–oxide interfacial dynamics and metastable state formation. Integrating machine learning frameworks with high-throughput screening and reactive environment modeling can accelerate the discovery of robust and versatile catalysts. Ultimately, predictive and durable LOHC dehydrogenation catalysts will be achieved by seamless integration of spatial control and dynamic insights into catalyst design. As evidence for structure sensitivity continue to grow, future research must embrace both the spatial complexity and temporal evolution of active sites to realize the next generation of efficient LOHC systems. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic dehydrogenation of liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHC) is recognized as a structure-sensitive reaction, where the geometry, coordination and electronic environment of active sites govern activity, selectivity and durability in a collective fashion. Previous studies on monometallic catalysts revealed the critical roles of particle size, facet exposure and local coordination structures in controlling H2 release rate and byproduct formation. Built on these principles, bimetallic catalysts and metal–metal oxide hybrid catalysts have recently attracted growing interest. The former enables tunable metal compositions to modulate active site ensembles, while the latter introduces interfacial structures tailoring both electronic properties and structural resilience. However, their surfaces undergo dynamic evolution under realistic reaction environments. These include atom migration, metal redistribution and metal–oxide interface reconstruction, which can generate metastable active states that differ significantly from as-synthesized structures. To capture these complexities, in situ/operando characterization needs to be integrated with adaptive modeling approaches that can represent transient configurations and reaction-driven structural transformations. This review highlights recent advances in designing active sites across monometallic, bimetallic and metal–metal oxide systems. Furthermore, it outlines future directions toward the rational catalyst design affording dynamically resilient active sites for LOHC dehydrogenation.
